The village café with three tables on the outside. Only m dressed up in traditional costume and carrying guns can b seen. These are Shestan Verdha, Cute Benja, Tod Allamani, Alush Gjati. Where you think it’s going to fall?

The comet. Nobody answers.

Stop talking nonsense, Cute; it’s not going to fall anywhere.
Then what is it doing up there? (CONTINUED)

Round and round, just like us here: leave home to come to the café, and then leave the café to go back home...
Don’t you ever stop? Doské Mokrari enters the café, with an elongated pumpkin hand.

This is how the comet looks: like a pumpkin. He pulls out a knife, cuts the pumpkin in half and throws seeds on the table. He shouts. DOSKE (cont’d) Get up, you morons; let’s go and save Albania, because she is in such an horrible mess already... And you have time to waste with that harlot up there in the sky?... Cute Benja is the most nervous of them all. He hits the ground with his tufted green-hide shoe. The chicken scatt away. Dust is raised. With a short stick he draws a line around his foot, something like a_ map.
Here you are! I draw a line around my foot, and what do I get? I get Albania. She’s no bigger than this tufted shoe of mine.

Listen here: even the Queen of England and the King of France know that Albania is here. They say they have lost the state seals, they have lost the maps, and the borders are nowhere to be found: nobody’s got a clue how to get them back. And you know why? Because the Greek pulls the rope on his side, and the Albanian pulls the rope on his side, and then here comes somebody else - say a Serb or a Macedonian - and does away with the markers at night. Then what’s next is that everybody going to pull out their guns, and it’s damn over. (CONTINUED)

Hey, hey, wait a minute. You want to drive me insane? How come this border issue is so hard to figure out? Wherever you have Albanians that’s where the borders should be traced. That this country is starving for a king, dammit! The men laugh. Shestan Verdha, a handsome man, thoughtful. He rolls a cigarette and puts it be s.2 p.3. keeps silent, tween his lips. Finally, Shestan stands and talks to them.
I say, tomorrow we leave for battle. There’s nothing worth waiting for. The village isn’t going anywhere, the women will take care of the farming. Who’s coming along?
Battle? What battle? Who are we fighting against? Silence. They all look at Shestan.
What we are fighting for, you mean.

Let’s leave first, and then play it by ear. There’s nothing to be done here anyway. All we do is sit in this café and talk. Let’s not waste any more time. We’ve got guns and bullets ready. Count me in, captain.
Captain? I didn’t say I was the captain. (CONTINUED)

Well, you should be. Where would we get someone better? Cute Benja stands up and approaches Shestan. CUTE (cont’d) I am all for battle, captain. If we don’t do it now, when are we going to fight for Albania? We’re fed up with words... They all stay solemnly silent.

We are going to fight for the German king. He is coming here to teach us how to become Europeans. Isn’t this good enough to fight for? They all nod, although Shestan’s words catch them a bit o guard. His mother looks sad. SHESTAN’S MOTHER You are such a sweet pretty boy! You have to get married as soon as you come back. Shestan hides his smile in his towel. SHESTAN’S MOTHER (cont’d) Did you hear what I just said? You should get married and have kids. It’s a shame to stay single. Everyone in the village is talking about this.
Yes, mother, I’1ll get married when I come back.

Roosters are crowing and dogs are barking in the village. Shestan Verdha meets his four friends Doské, Tod, Alush, and Cute. They are all dressed up handsomely, with their tight suits and their kilts. Their weapons glisten clean. (CONTINUED)

Gun in shoulder, and food bags on their back, the men lea the village. Suddenly Doské stops as if he remembered something. He pulls off the gun from his shoulder.
Wait a minute! Where are we going, without a map?!
What do we need a map for, Doské? It’s going to mess us up! Shestan is waiting for them.

No way, captain. We can’t go nowhere without a map. Not serious you know? The map shows the roads, shows the state with its borders and its borders show the state. That’s the way it is. Then why don’t you just shut up and listen to me. OK.. Where the heck are we? He points his finger at a line on the map, then rolls the and puts it in his bag. SHESTAN (cont’d) We go walk down this river which flows to the sea, that is west. Do you get it?

location: PLATEAU. MOUNTAIN SCENERY. CENTRAL ALBANIA. DAY. 9

text: Sunny day. A plateau in Central Albania. In the distance, stunning mountain range. The fighters, gathered around Shestan, listen carefully to his tentative reading from a half-torn Albanian newspaper. It shows a photo of the kin Von Wied, his wife Sophia Schomburg and some officials in Tirana.

(voice over) "The German prince Wilhelm Wied arrives in Durrés. He has been appointed King of Albanians, by the Great Powers." Shestan looks at his friends. SHESTAN (cont’d) "Wilhelm Wied was received today by a crowd of hundreds of Muslim, Catholic and Orthodox Albanians, who welcomed their new King." Silence.
Can you believe this?
Well, now it’s too late to do anything. It’s our fault too, because we weren’t able to come up with a king ourselves.

What’s the big deal with this king?! Is it because he’s a foreigner? Do you know that even the Greeks used to have a German king for more than thirty years, not to mention the Bulgarians? Cute keeps looking at the photos on the paper.
Bullshit! Ain’t worth nothing these newspapers, captain!

A crowd of Cam refugees (Albanians expelled from Northern Greece) and Jews (banned from Thessalonica): men, women a kids, with their carts, horses and a truck as well, comin the opposite direction of Shestan’s detachment with their mule and canon. (CONTINUED)
Any fighting where you’re coming from? The Jews don’t understand. Doské gestures. DOSKE (cont’d) Fighting ! War ?!
Wait a minute, they don’t seem to get it. Did you see any fighting...?
Thessalonica, Helada...
These are Greeks, did you hear that? They don’t speak Albanian, they are Jews from Thessalonica.
No, no, what are you talking about? We’re no Greek, we’re Cam. He says something in Greek as well.
I’m sorry, man. I took you for a Greek. Where are you heading to?
We fled from Thessalonica to come here; they told us nobody will do us any harm. The Cam translates.

He says they’ve fled Thessalonica to come to Albania, because nobody will ever touch them here. In Caméria, that was some carnage. They slew our sons, took our land and our cattle away from us, and then sent the police to chase us away. God only knows what will become of us. For them it’s even worse: they’ve been chased out from every place.
Why did you leave? (CONTINUED)
Massacre. They came at night to kill and ransack us. The Cam translates from Greek
He speaks of massacre, they came at night to kill and ransack them.
And where are you heading to now, you poor people?

We don’t know. All we need is a piece of land, to get some shelter. These Jews are going to Elbasan. They say they have some friends there. At least they have some gold on them to survive. How far is it to Elbasan?
Two-days walk. Doské approaches Shestan and whispers in his ear. DOSKE (cont’d) Let’s take their gold, captain. We’ve got a war to fight, damn it
Enough, Doské. We’re not here to rob people. These are people, like us
Have a safe trip. And hurry up, so that night won’t catch you on the road. One of the Jews starts shouting in Greek.

No gasoline left! I told you not to take it! He inserts a stick in the fuel tank and takes it out. It dry, nothing’s left. Shestan’s detachment sets off with c and mule, while the Cams and Jews unload stuff from the t and divide it among the horses. 10  14 s.11 p.11.
The five-fighter detachment walks by a hamlet half hidden smoke. They see people cutting grass with sickles and bur it in heaps.
Captain, these are Albanians that’s for sure.
How do you know?
Look at their faces, withered up under the sun.
Cute, do not insult us Albanians.
This is true, that’s how we look. That’s what the Sun does, dry up the skin.
Enough, you two! The fighters approach with great caution, holding their weapons ready. The peasants quit working and greet them.
Do you happen to know where there is fighting going on? The peasants shake their heads. They mumble something, ta to each other, then one of them nods.

Ah, yes, I know. In the East. You see these mountains, over there ? Shestan and his men look at the ridge the man is pointing PEASANT (cont’d) You have to climb this mountain here: it’s a shortcut - if you go around it, be too long. You see the pass? When you’1l be on the other side, you’1l see a plain. It’s not there. Shestan and his men exchange a puzzled look. (CONTINUED)

11  12 s.11 p.12. PEASANT (cont’d) In the distance, on the other side of that plain, you will see a second mountain. As you go through the pass of this second mountain you’1l see another plain, with a river. That’s where the slaughtering is taking place, on both banks. Two more fighters join Shestan’s group

It’s raining. An old ottoman bridge, long and narrow, thr on a gigantic arch. The fighters stop to let pass two peo First is a man over sixty, with his traditional Albanian suit, comfortably sitting on his horse, and protecting himself from the rain with a big black umbrella. Behind h young woman follows on foot, dressed in fancy-colored clothes, dripping under the rain. She wears a cross aroun her neck. The men greet each other, hands on their hearts
Have you heard anything about any fighting, old man?
Fighting?! No fighting here. In the South, maybe.

What South? South is where we come from. The man on the horse motions the girl to move, so that sh not too close to the men. Shestan stares at the girl. She looks back, blushing. The old man seems to get confused. Shestan keeps staring at the girl.
Where do you come from?
Our village is one day’s walk from here.
And she, who is she? He shows the girl. The man on the horse doesn’t seem to l this question.
She is my daughter. Why do you ask? (CONTINUED)
12  s.12 p.13. Cute laughs out loud. Doské nudges him.Shestan looks at t beautiful girl with her dripping clothes, then at her fat comfortable and dry under his umbrella.
Where are you going?
I am taking my daughter to the nuns.
Why?
Excuse me?
I just asked you “Why?”. It’s war. It could be dangerous. The old man is sweating fear.
The country’s back with the Turkish Sultan, that’s why. My daughter will be safe with the nuns. They’11 give her food and shelter. Then, I won’t even have to worry about the dowry and the wedding.
What are you talking about?
The Sultan’s armies are coming! Our wives and daughters, they’1l have to cover their faces! The fighters don’t buy what the man says.
Don’t lie to us, it doesn’t suit your moustache.
My moustache’s none of your business, sir!
Yes it is! And Albania has no business with Turkey whatsoever The empire’s dead, it’s history. (CONTINUED)
Don’t you understand, you fool? The Turkish Sultan is coming! It’s in the papers. It’s over, go home! Shestan comes nearer to Agnes’ father and talks coldly, pointing at the exhausted girl.
Get down! Let her ride the horse! The man looks scared, but he doesn’t budge. Shestan cocks rifle. Cute, Doské, Tod and Alush try to stop him.
Stop it, captain. Don’t get intoa blood feud. These people are Catholic. Their customs are harsh.
Quarreling over trifles, methinks. Shestan is unconvinced. The others try to stop him.

I don’t care what he is. I know what I am doing. Get out of the way! He approaches Agnes’ father and waits for him to dismount SHESTAN (cont’d) Get off, and let the girl mount. She’s your daughter. The man falters, then gets off the horse with a frown. Shestan grabs the girl by her arm. Agnes tries to resist by evading his grip, but Shestan grasps her foot, and tri to place it on the stirrup. Motions her to get on the hor She doesn’t move.

Get on the horse, kid. It’s for your own good. Your daddy won’t say anything. Shestan looks at the girl, then at her father frozen in anger, and finally greets him, placing the palm of his ri hand over his heart. Agnes’ father coldly returns the greeting, then hits the horse with his stick. The horse j forward. Shestan can’t take his eyes off Agnes. Agnes sta back at Shestan. They are in love. Move! (CONTINUED)
14  s.12 p.15. Agnes looks at Shestan’s beautiful eyes. Shestan’s eyes follow her, sadly. Cute shouts at Agnes’ father.

Sultan my ass, you fucking bastard! He raises the gun and gets ready to shoot, but Shestan doesn’t let him. Cute (cont'd) You must be out of your mind, old man! Locking up such a beauty, such a goddamn beauty! Poor girl! Shestan, through his binoculars, sees the Agnes turning towards him and trying to find out where he is. Dad!

15  13 s.12 p.16. AGNES FATHER (cont’d) Eat. She doesn’t reply.
Dad, I don’t want to go there.
What are you talking about?! You have left home already. Everyone in the village knows you are going to become God’s daughter now. Agnes seems to be shocked by her father’s words.
Dad, are you telling me the truth?
Of course, yes. Silence AGNES FATHER (cont'd) How is it that you don’t want to go there? That’s God’s house. Agnes insists, still shaking from the cold and emotion.
Father, why are you locking me up in that place? Her father hesitates, doesn’t look her in the eyes.
Where can I take you then daughter?
Home, dad. The father doesn’t answer. Agnes keeps her head lowered. man rolls a cigarette.

Big plains in Central Albania. Red rebel Flags with the Ottoman crescent can be seen waving all over the place wi the green muslim flag. Hundreds of peasant soldiers, some rags and others in uniforms of the former Turkish-Ottoman army are dancing and beating the drums and singing (CONTINUED)

Give us our daddy! Give us our daddy! Long Live the Sultan! Long Live Albania! The dervishes and the mullahs pray and dance like lunatic Steam coming from the huge cauldrons as well as the sharp smell of meat being roasted over the fire are everywhere. Their chief, Kus Babaj, is showing off among them, wearin old Turkish general uniform. Then they sing: "We set off for paradise, but ended up in hell, Albania, you whore, you've poisoned us all." Cute seals Doské’s mouth with the palm of his hand. Doské tries to get away. The others try to get at Doské, they a angry.

That’s not me, you jerk; these are Kus Babaj’s thugs! Are you deaf?
Doské, stop acting like a fool! How can you call your own land that way?! They are all standing up now, guns ready. Shestan gets in middle. (CONTINUED)
That’s what they sing, what do I know?
Even if they sing it, you don’t have to! What a shame, if anybody hears it! Doské is stunned. SHESTAN (cont’d)
Doské is silent. SHESTAN (cont’d)
Yeah, OK... Doské starts to shout. DOSKE (cont’d) Long Live Albania, Long Live King Wied!

Long Live Albania! SHESTAN’S MEN (all together) Long Live Albania, Long Live King Wied! No reaction from Kus Babajs’ camp. The drum beats covered their shouts. EXT. CONVENT’S GATE. DAY 14 The gate opens and Mother Superior appears. She greets Ag and her father. He has tears in his eyes.
What is your name?
Agnes.

Another nun is coarsely cutting Agnes’ hair with shears. Skinny Nun is watching. Agnes stares at the mops passing front of her eyes and falling on the floor. She looks distraught. The Skinny Nun is amused. The nun gives Agnes small mirror. She stares at her very short hair.
Go take a bath now.
The nuns are eating. Agnes stares at her soup, lost in thoughts. The Skinny Nun sitting next to her takes a piec bread and gives it to her.
Eat! Move your spoon! Agnes doesn’t react. Mother Superior looks at her. In sec all the nuns have stopped eating, and wait for Agnes to d something. Silence.

MOTHER SUPERIOR (cont'd) If you don’t want to eat, go to your room! We shall attend to you later on. Agnes leaves the refectory. Everyone starts eating again. There is a low whispering all around. (CONTINUED)
19  18 s.17 p.20. MOTHER SUPERIOR (cont’d) Silence! The murmurs end.
Agnes is on her knees scrubbing the floor of the corridor with a brush and soap. She looks exhausted and sad. Mothe Superior comes and stands in front of her. She speaks ina low, but harsh voice.
I knew it. As soon as I saw you, I knew it. What was happening with you.
What was happening to me, Mother?

You think of a man. Do not deny it. I know it. Agnes looks up at her, wide eyed. MOTHER SUPERIOR (cont’d) Don’t tell me anything. We do not talk of these things, here. Agnes gets up and throws the water to wash off the foam o the ground. Mother Superior approaches her, and stares in her eyes. MOTHER SUPERIOR (cont’d) When you came here, you brought your body and your soul with you. Right? She speaks with passion, and tears appear in her eyes, whereas Agnes looks frozen. Silence. MOTHER SUPERIOR (cont‘d) Right?
Yes, Mother.
But you cannot keep them both now. You have to decide which one to give up. Right?
Yes, Mother. There is a silence, but Agnes doesn’t seem overwhelmed. (CONTINUED)
20  s.18 p.21. AGNES (cont’d) Is it true that an army is coming from Istanbul, to cover Albanian women with veils?
Who told you this?
My father. He told me that they are going to cover us all, from head to toe, like their wives... Mother Superior interrupts her with a sharp voice.
No, this is not true. Only God’s will shall prevail. Agnes remains apparently shy.

location: CROSSROADS WITH FOREIGN POWER FLAGS. DAY. 19

text: Shestan’s detachment of fifteen warriors has stopped at another mountain pass. A sign has been put there, which reads: REPUBLIC OF KORCA. FRENCH PROTECTORATE. Shestan signals everybody to stop.
The French don’t seem to be far
Shsh! Let’s listen for a while, just in case there’s any fighting going on! They stop dead in their tracks and turn their heads: sile Doské grabs Shestan’s arm. SHESTAN (cont’d) What now?
These French, are they with us, or against us?
How should I know? They walk a little more and discover at the top of the sl a French military outpost. (CONTINUED)

21  s.19 p.22. They are stunned by all the flags they suddenly see: - Gr Britain’s, France’s, Germany’s, Italy’s and The Austro- Hungarian Empire’s - hoisted on a rectangular metallic structure. The flags dance wildly under the wind. The place is guarded by armed soldiers, wearing the Frenc army uniform. They look alert. Shestan waves at them. SHESTAN (cont’d) Don’t shoot! What kind of flags are these?
The first one is British, captain. The second Austrian, the third Italian, and the rest, I don’t know.
And our flag, how come it isn’t shown?
Why don’t you ask them, captain?
Who the heck is going to talk to them?
Let me do it, captain. He approaches the guards, who point their weapons at him.
Arrétez-vous! Doské stops dead in his tracks. The fighters ready their weapons. Doské talks to them aloud:
Albania?.. Flag, flag, Albania! The guards do not reply. Doské points at the flags and repeats his words. DOSKE (cont’d) The flag, where? The flag?
Forget it, Doské. They do not understand. Ask them about the war. Use that word of yours.
War, war! Where? War, war? (CONTINUED)
22  20 s.19 p.23. Doské accompanies his words with ample gestures, opening arms and pointing with his finger all around.
No war, no war!

War, War! Bang, bang! He imitates the sound of a shooting weapon. The guards do understand. One of them produces a whistle and blows hard The other one does the same. Shestan and his men do not understand. By now all the guards are blowing their whist
Let’s go, captain! It doesn’t look good. They’re getting nervous. Their whole army will soon be on us!
Let’s go, then. The fighters trot away, as the guards keep blowing their whistles all around the place.

location: SQUARE OF A MOSLEM VILLAGE. DAY 20

text: The village square. Empty. The door of the mosque is open None of the village inhabitants is around. Carts and plou can be seen scattered all around. The fighters quench the thirst at the stone fountain, and fill up their gourds.

Look! They surrender! I swear to God, they are coming here to surrender! Two men dressed with a French army uniform, enter the vil square. One of them holds a white flag. Shestan frowns. T Frenchmen come close and give the military salute. Nobody replies. One of the Frenchmen starts speaking a bad Alban
Where is commander?
What do you want?

French commander wants to meet Albanian commander. Shestan looks at his companions, but doesn’t say a word. French give the military salute and leave. 23  21 s.21 p.24. EXT. FRENCH COMMANDER’S TENT. DAY. 21 Shestan, Doské, and Cute have stopped in front of the Fre commander’s tent in the shade of a couple of tall trees. French commander is patronizing them, by smoking a long cigar. He turns to his interpreter, but Shestan interrupt him.
Whose side are you on? His words are translated into French.
Pardon me?
I asked: whose side are you on? The French commander clears his voice, to make the whole thing appear very formal and serious.
He seems such an asshole to me. The French commander turns to his interpreter, but the interpreter seems to have trouble making out Cute’s words just shakes his head reproachfully.

Let’s be frank to each other. France’s wish is that the situation in the Balkans be stabilized, that’s why we are here. Do you really believe that the Austrian-Hungarian Empire is a friend and protector of your country’s interests? I know you cannot believe such a thing. The truth is that they have their own interests to pursue, and you legendary commander, should avoid falling into this trap! You must also rest assured that France’s policy, with regards to...
Enough already! He puts his hand on his gun. Everybody freezes. The Frenc Commander keeps talking with the shade of a smile on his lips.
It’s such a pity that we cannot find a common ground so that we can proceed with our talks. (CONTINUED)

24  s.21 p.25. FRENCH COMMANDER(cont'd) I consider your presence, dear commander, as an expression of our efforts, yours and mine, to... As the French interpreter is translating, Shestan pulls o the map and shows it to the Frenchman.
Do you know what this is? The interpreter translates.

head_text.subj: SEPARATIST ORTHODOX PRINCEDOM OF NORTHERN EPIRUS

text: Shestan reads it out aloud.

It says “The Separatist Orthodox Princedom of Northern Epirus”. What’s wrong with these people?! He brings the sign down and throws it in the river. Shest opens the wrinkled map, straightens it out and places it his knees. He starts marking with a pencil the road they covered already. They gather around him.
We’ve done a lot of walking, damn it. Shestan draws a line on the map pointing north-east.
Captain, I’m afraid this place here is Macedonia.
How do you know?

Here, look: it reads “Ohrid”, and there: “Skopje”. And these are the lakes. Here you have the villages with Albanian names, and there those with Slav names. We’re in the wrong place. We had better go back. They start looking around.
What are you talking about? we haven’t seen any Macedonian so far. (CONTINUED)
He’s right. Haven’t seen any of those. Just go ahead, captain, and draw your line, because this is still our land. Shestan hesitates.
Hold on a minute. This is Kosovo and this is Serbia, and I have Albania here, Greece is there, and this place here, you think it’s Macedonia, right?
I’ve been in Skopje myself, two years ago.
And how was it?
People all over the place; stores, mosques, churches; just like here.
What are you talking about? Can’t be just like here.
I swear, it was just like here. Only the language was different.
Any Albanian there?
A lot.
Good people? They all look at Cute disapprovingly.
There can’t be any bad Albanians for God’s sake.

Of course not! With a pencil, Shestan circles the Albanian territories o the Turkish map. Then, he crumples it and tucks it in his belt. Starts rolling a cigarette. Agnes is asleep. Shesta covers her with his cape. She wakes up, and stares at Shestan, with fearful eyes. (CONTINUED)
Sleep now. The fighters smoke and stay silent. Shestan goes under a to rest. Cute Benja smiles and chats with Doské.
It’s so weird, Doské, sometimes I don’t even know what I’m talking about. Have you noticed that?
No.
That’s odd, ‘cause LI...
I know, I know. Without thinking. I do that sometimes. But you know, what’s important is what we do; what we do we do is what we are.

Doské, you know what I miss most? I miss a piece of warm pie so much... My wife can cook it so well, you wouldn’t believe. I won’t give up the ghost till I’ve had a real meal one last time: a cheese and onion pie, and a bowl of thin yoghurt, and then a nice little nap by the fireplace. Nothing can beat that.
Cute, for God’s sake, why are you telling me all this about a cheese pie? Can’t think of anything else?

And you know what I miss too? Doské sighs. CUTE (cont’d) A wedding party. Just imagine if we had a wedding party. Everyone dancing: first the men. Just think of those women dancing. You just have to look at one of them. Goose pimples all over.
Is that what you call it? (CONTINUED)

50  s.46 p.51. Murmur of water from the river and birds chirping in the trees. One of the fighters produces a clarinet and starts playing a famous tune. Cute Benja and Shestan are dancing Other fighters join in, until the dance becomes really hu with about thirty people in quilts, hanging on from each other’s shoulders, jumping up and down and screaming like wild beasts out of pleasure. Agnes wakes up, startled. Sh sees the men dancing. She keeps her eyes trained on Shest handsome face. While everyone is dancing, a group of people wearing different clothes sneaks in the back. These are Macedonia peasants, armed with rifles and hay forks. Nobody notices them. They stop at a short distance from Shestan’s fighte They wave their hands in order to attract the dancers’ attention, but in vain. Finally, the Macedonians shoot th weapons in the air. The Albanian fighters freeze and look around. Nobody has been hit. The two sides stare at each other, challengingly.
(in Macedonian) Who are you?
Who are you? None of the Macedonians replies. CUTE (cont’d) (in Albanian) It looks like we have trespassed on the goddamned Macedonian territory! Both sides remain silent.
Don’t shoot. Just stay calm. He starts to walk towards the Macedonians. Doské follows in order to stop him.
Don’t get any closer, captain. They are armed.
Stay where you are. I can talk to them. Shestan walks towards the Macedonians. They wait for him. Shestan’s people stay ready for combat. Shestan stops in front of the Macedonians. (a1) (CONTINUED)
This is Macedonia. What’s your business here?

We lost our way. The map confused us. Now we are going back. My men were dancing to shed off the fatigue. The Macedonians whisper to each other. Shestan’s fighters inching closer on their guard. The Macedonian peasants li to him in silence, still unconvinced.
We thought you were preparing for a wedding.
Wedding? No, oh yes, but my men just love to rehearse before the wedding. We are expecting the best dancers.
Mmm, mmm. What kind of music is that?
Why do you ask?
‘Cause we know these tunes, too. But we play them properly, much better than you do.

Well, that’s why we’re neighbors. Divided by a river. He offers the Macedonian his tobacco pouch. SHESTAN (cont’d) Here, roll a cigarette. The Macedonian hesitates, looks around. Doské and Cute ha taken out their own tobacco pouches. One of the Macedonia accepts the offer, with words of gratitude. Everyone else follows. The sight of these scores of men smoking evokes feeling of peace. The Macedonian is now staring at Agnes. turns to Shestan.
That girl over there.. do you use her for fun? (CONTINUED)
52  47 s.46 p.53. The Macedonian peasants laugh and stare at Agnes. She get scared. Shestan looks at them with a frown.
No. We aren’t here to have that kind of fun.
Why don’t you give us the girl? We’1l pay you handsomely. Shestan tries to control himself. Some Macedonian peasant giggle. Shestan starts talking, his voice not disguising hidden threat.

We have been trusted with that girl! Nobody can touch her. Trusted! Bessa! The given word! He has now switched to Albanian. The Macedonian peasant m it, thinks for a while, then replies in bad Albanian.
I see! Trusted. Vera, in trust. Didn’t know.

Yeah, Vera. Given word. Sacred. Both sides stare at each other. SHESTAN (cont’d) We must go now. God bless you! Shestan salutes them with hand on his heart. As they cros the river, Agnes walks behind Shestan, holding at his coa The Macedonian peasants watch them from across the river, still suspicious.
Shestan’s fighters have set up fires. Through his binocul Shestan watches the Macedonians across the river, as they light fires, too.
I say let’s get out of here, captain. Nobody knows what gifts the night will bear.
Let’s go, captain. We’1ll manage to find our way, somehow. (CONTINUED)
Hey, what are you talking about? We have no clue what direction to take whatsoever. We risk trespassing in Greece or Macedonia once again.

We stay here. Didn’t do them wrong, neither killed nor robbed them. We just got lost. He turns around, notices Agnes who is staring at him. SHESTAN (cont’d) You know what? He smiles. SHESTAN (cont’d) Let’s dance. Yes indeed: let’s dance! All night long till morn’. So we all stay awake: us and them. Halil, come here. The man called Halil approaches him quickly. SHESTAN (cont’d) Play, and we’1ll dance. Now! Play loud! Halil whistles, and two men show up, carrying a violin an tambourine. The music starts. Shestan’s men get up and st dancing by the fire. On the other bank, the Macedonians l surprised. Shestan’s men jump up in the air graciously, t kilts fluttering like wings. The Macedonians watch, while one of them leaves for the village. The dance goes on and on. Ton Now it’s the Macedonians’ turn to start dancing, on the opposite bank of the river. Their dance is similar to the Albanians’. They are gradually racing each other. The Macedonian orchestra consists of a clarinet, a violin and drum. Shestan and his fighters watch on. Now they have to wait for the Macedonians to finish dancing. They wait covered with sweat. The Macedonian dance seems to go on a on forever.
Captain, these guys will never stop. They are cheating. Be better to alternate our numbers, don’t you think? (CONTINUED)

They’11 get tired soon, Doské, just be patient. But the Macedonians keep dancing on and on, jumping aroun screaming out of pleasure. Ton They look tired now and some of them give up and fall to ground. But new ones join the dance, and it seems it will never end. . Now the Albanians resume dancing without waiting for th Macedonians to stop. The race becomes real: which group w outperform the other? The excitement gets out of control. Agnes stays crouched, scared by the men’s fury. . The dancers’ crowd is getting thinner on both sides because some of those dancing are now down on the ground. Still, a couple of men hold on. Angry at their opponents’ perseverance, they keep moving and shouting in Macedonian Albanian.

location: RIVER BANKS. BOTH SIDES OF THE RIVER. SUNRISE. 48

text: Crack of dawn. Macedonians and Albanians lie on the groun sleeping, snoring aloud. Smoke comes out of the fires.
Shestan’s fighters march through a sunlit mountain landsc Agnes follows Shestan. Shestan turns around and stares at her. The girl looks worn out.
We still have to walk a lot. Agnes doesn’t reply. She gets closer and smiles at him.
You are very handsome.
You say that again and I kill you. Agnes looks at him with affection
Are you a Muslim? Shestan answers softly
Yes (CONTINUED)
Do you have a wife?
No, why?
How come?
How come? I don’t know.
Well, you are a man, that’s why. Shestan is confused and doesn’t know what to say.
Then what?
Nothing. Just saying... He looks at her. Agnes lowers her eyes, hides her smile. Shestan hurries away.
Shestan knocks on the convent’s main gate. No one seems t show up. Finally he climbs over the gate.
Anybody there? No answer. Agnes waits. Shestan shouts out once again. No answer.
No, I don’t want to stay here. Take me with you!
No! This is where you’re going to stay, it’s safe, and the sisters be nice to you.
No. They are not nice. Witches, you mean. I am scared... He motions Cute to help him. They grab Agnes and let her the wall. Mother Superior appears with three nuns but the don’t open the main gate.
Go away, please. You cannot stay here! (CONTINUED)
56  51 52 53 s.50 p.57. Agnes stares at Shestan still sitting on the wall.
Sister, you take her please, for God’s sake. Can’t keep her longer, we’re bound for battle. If we leave her on the road, the beast will make mincemeat of her.
May God help you! Mother Superior, nuns and Agnes enter the convent while Shestan and his men leave.
Agnes shouts are heard.
(off screen) No, I don’t want to stay here! I don’t want to stay with you people! The Skinny Nun leaves her room and walks stealthily in th vaulted corridor. Agnes bangs her door
Agnes stands behind the door of her room. She hears some noise coming from the end of the corridor. Suddenly, the opens and four nuns come in, grab her, take her to the washroom, and undress her.

Agnes is in Mother Superior’s office, sitting on a stool. hair is still wet, she has a new nun’s uniform, she looks nervous. After a while, the door opens and Mother Superio shows up, along with Rosseta, the Skinny Nun. Mother Supe sits down in front of Agnes, then speaks softly, witha threat.

Sister Rosseta, Agnes will stay with us until the war is over. You will have to take care of her. May you love each other through your love in God. Mother Superior crosses herself, and says a prayer. Agnes watches them closely. 57  54 s.54 p.58.

A beautiful sunny day. A lake surrounded by an amphitheat of hills. Shestan’s fighters walking along the shoreline across a couple of signs that read: ISLAMIC PRINCEDOM OF CENTRAL ALBANIA. WE ADMIT REFUGEES FROM KOSOVO, BOSNIA AND MACEDONIA.

head_text.subj: WE DO NOT ADMIT REFUGEES FROM SERBIA, GREECE AND BULGARIA

text: A procession of Catholic believers wearing icons and a primitive Christ statue walk pass them singing. Alush sta at the Christ’s statue. The procession stops on top of th hill, and lays down the cross. They seem to be waiting fo something. Worried, Alush comes to Shestan.
What the heck are they doing, captain?
Dunno. Maybe praying.
I don’t think so. There’s something fishy going on there. Look at them! They look like they’ve lost their mind!
Whatever. They’re not armed.
You never know, captain.
Hey, hey, wait a minute. We can’t fight the whole world here! what they are doing it’s none of our business, okay? Alush rolls a cigarette. Cute comes running.
We got the wrong direction, captain! We’re walking in circles! Doské smiles.
No, no, we’ve always been heading north. Just keep walking! Shestan is staring at the Catholic mob on top of the hill who now pray to the Christ’s statue. 58  55 56 57 s.55 p.59.

The fighters plod their way through the mud. An artillery shell whistles through the air. The shell flies towards t fighters and hits Alush Tabutgjati who’s drinking water f his canteen. Alush’s body is split in two. He expires promptly, in a pool of his blood.
What was that, my brothers?! What was that? It came out of the blue.. God have mercy upon us!
Bury him in a good place. Right there! He points at the muddy plain.

The fighters run to cross the river. The green religious with the crescent and the red Sultan flag appear on the opposite bank zigzagging above the reeds. Shestan motions men to get back into the forest at the foot of the mounta Shots are heard, then drum beats, then people yelling ”Al akhbar” but no one is to be seen.

The detachment is engaged in battle. The forest scenery i wonderful, but all around we see glimpses of chaos. Men hating other men. Everybody fighting against everybody. Kus Babaj’s men hoist their Ottoman Empire flags, yell an play their drums. All are both exhausted and hysterical, enraged and some panicking. Dead and wounded everywhere. Doské, runs towards Kus Babaj’s shelter - he looks like h lost his mind altogether. He screams as he hits an enemy his bayonet. Blood splatters him red all over and covers face.

Come here, you scum of the earth; come here so that I can make a shish kebab of your bodies. You sonofabitch! He rushes to Kus Babaj but his guards throw him back. Dos keeps shouting. DOSKE (cont’d) Kus Babaj, I’1l go piss on your grave! You shitty bastard! (CONTINUED)
If I get you, I’1l have your balls crushed, you pork of an infidel!
But you can’t get me, you old carrion. Come here, if you have the balls! Just come here! I am invincible, I am a hero! Kus Babaj’s rebels shout in chorus:

Give us our daddy, give us our daddy! They beat their drums angrily. Shestan’s tries to help Do but all he gets is a bayonet hit in the arm. Shestan knoc him down with the butt of his gun. Doské collapses on the ground. The beautiful meadow is now littered with the man dead and wounded.

My God, everybody’s dead! Kus Babaj’s rebels withdraw and disappear behind the tree No more shots. Only moans and cries for help from the wounded. The rebels’ hysterical cackle is still heard thr the forest. The fighters withdraw too, dragging their wounded. Shestan gets to Doské and tries to find a word o courage for him. SHESTAN (cont’d) Don’t give in, Doské! We got to get back home.

No I won’t, my captain. I ama hero, I’m not going to die. That’s impossible. Just give me some raki. Cute gives him raki with a smile. Shestan arm is all red blood. Doské holds him tight, right on his wound. Shestan grins.
Outside the convent’s walls. Doské lies in front of the m gate. He is about to expire. Nuns are taking care of him.
Play the bells now that I’m still alive.. Play the bells, I say! Shestan looks at Mother Superior. She nods with her head, a young nun runs to the bells. (CONTINUED)

60  s.58 p.61. Shestan turns his eyes towards the inner door of the conv Waits. The bells are tolling. Doské has a smile. DOSKE (cont’d) You hear? They are ringing for me! Shestan approaches Mother Superior.
Please, Mother Superior. Keep him here. We cannot take him with us.
God forgive me, we cannot. I’m so sorry.
But Mother, we are from a village in the South.
Then why don't you go bury him there?
Mother, our village is far away. We don’t know when we shall be back. You see, we cannot keep a dead man with us for weeks. He’s not going to last. We have to give him a proper burial.
He’s none of us. We cannot bury him. Shestan is getting nervous.

How so? Is he not a human being? Okay, just leave him outside, so the dogs devour him. As he speaks, he catches a glimpse of two nuns showing up with a couple of bread loafs. He freezes. One of the nuns Agnes. She stops in front of him. He looks at her with affection. Agnes gives him a smile, hands him a bread loa Shestan accepts it. Agnes keeps her hands on the loaf, to him know that he must look at the bread, carefully. Shest is aware of her silent request but doesn’t understand. Ag takes the loaf away from his hands, and puts it in his ba Agnes then leaves, but she turns back once again, to have last look at Shestan. Shestan seems lost. Doské is yellin the nuns.
Damn you! I am dying! Play the bells! (CONTINUED)
61  59 s.58 p.62. DOSKE(cont'd) Don’t want to go anywhere, don’t want to stay with those witches!
Watch your mouth, Doské! You can’t talk like this. We are guests here.

Play the bells! Christ is resurrected! I don’t go to church, Me? I go to battle! No, no, I go home. Tomorrow! One of the nuns rings the bells, energetically. Doské is and more delirious. DOSKE (cont’d) Do you hear it or not? Please brothers, take me home, please! Shestan turns his head, looking for Agnes, but he can’t s her anymore in the courtyard. The nuns have already close the main gate. Outside the convent’s walls the fighters a having their meal, and resting. Someone is already singin SHESTAN’S MAN “Albania, why don’t you resist Albania, why are you melting away, Like flowers in March Like snow in April?” The others sing along.

Agnes is in her room. The men’s singing is heard coming f outside. She prays. She looks at Shestan through the wind and cries. She follows every single move of his: the way walks, the steps he takes, his posture, the gestures he m with his hands; she tries to catch his eyes as he turns occasionally, towards the convent’s windows.

Please forgive me, God! She falls on the bed, face forward. She prays to the wood figurine of Jesus, but she’s so badly in love with Shesta AGNES (cont’d) No, I can’t pray. Oh, God, why did you make him come here? Suddenly, there is a knock on the door. Agnes stands up abruptly. Wipes off her tears. The knock is heard again. opens the door: Mother Superior.
(CONTINUED)
62  60 s.59 p.63. Mother Superior and Agnes sit facing each other.
My dear, God will help you forget, if you help yourself, that is.
I can’t, Mother. I have sinned.

We all have. They stay silent for a while. MOTHER SUPERIOR (cont’d) If you hope time will make it easier for you, it isn’t going to happen. If you wait for a man, he might come to you, if he is not killed in the war. But if you wait for God, he will certainly come to you.
When is God coming, Mother?
I never ask myself that kind of question.
Why don’t you, Mother? Is it a sin?

No, Agnes, it’s not. It’s just that you can’t answer it. The waiting itself is the answer. Agnes looks at her, taken aback. Mother Superior stands u rather satisfied with herself, and walks out of the room.

The Skinny Nun’s screams are heard echoing throughout the convent. Rosetta has lost her mind, and the other nuns ar holding her firmly, so that she doesn’t hurt herself bump against the walls or the floor. Agnes watches the scene f her bedroom door. The Skinny Nun screams, and the nuns hold her above the ground, as they try to tie her up. Mother Superior orders them to follow her. Someone tries to muffle Rosseta’s screams. Two other nuns cry, upset by their friend’s breakdown. After a while, the screams can’t be heard any more. Agnes stays at the door of her room, terrified and lonely. 63  61 62 s.61 p.64.
The nuns are gathered in the refectory. Mother Superior speaks.

I have bad news for all of us. The king is leaving. These are times of troubles. We must be prepared: anything can happen. Let’s pray to our Lord, Jesus Christ, so that he grants us protection. The nuns cross themselves and pray. MOTHER SUPERIOR (cont’d) This is why I will not tell you, because I love you all: those who want to leave - whoever they are - can do it now. Long silence. Nobody moves. MOTHER SUPERIOR (cont’d) God bless you all. Mother Superior keeps an eye on Agnes. The Skinny Nun loo at her too. But Agnes keeps her head down, without reacti to Mother Superior’s words.
Shestan and his fighters are on a long and narrow road through the mountains of Northern Albania. They come acro road sign that says:

They knock the sign down and destroy it. Shestan lays his on the ground and looks for the map. he opens it, and pic up the bread loaf Agnes gave him. He shares it in half wi Cute. Cute finds a letter inside his share. He cleans it and opens it. But he cannot read. He looks around to make sure no one has seen him, then comes near Shestan and giv him the letter.
Here, that’s what I found, inside your loaf.
Inside?
What’s in it? (CONTINUED)
It’s for me.
For you? Who wrote it? Shestan cannot find a proper answer. He has figured out t letter comes from Agnes. CUTE (cont’d) Read it to me, captain, please!
This is from the Bible, Cute. The Christians’ Bible. God’s words.
God’s? No kidding! Please read them to me, captain. Shestan reflects, but his eyes are dancing on the sheet o paper.
God says: “Thou shalst not kill!”. Cute Benja reflects then shakes his head and resumes chew his bread.
Allah says that too. But who sent you this letter?
God did, Cute.
God? Why would God write you?
It is a sign, Cute.
What is this sign, captain?! I don’t get it.
God says we should go back home. Cute Benja speaks with a trembling voice.
God is right. That’s what I say too, let’s go back to our kids. Shestan reads the letter in low voice. (CONTINUED)

“God says to Moses: That man who loves a woman but who hasn’t married her yet, let him go back to her, because if he is killed in battle she will become someone else's...” The letter starts trembling in his hands.

A mosque in the background. The peasants in Turkish attir and a group of dervishes dressed in white, are listening the sermon of Ahmet the dervish. Ahmet is standing on a h boulder and keeps wagging the stick he holds in his hand. drummer crisscrosses the crowd, beating his drum. He stop when the dervish starts talking.

Everybody’s gone, Allah, but You! You remained in the sky so that we could remain here on Earth. Father Sultan, please forgive her, because she hardly knew what she was doing; she turned down your helping hand, and preferred a German to you; a German who can’t even keep his pants up. What a shame! ! Shestan’s detachment enters the small square, holding up King’s flag. The peasants receive them coldly. The dervis stops his speech. Cute Benja approaches a group of men an salutes them.
Greetings! Can we buy some food here?

No food here in the village. Only Allah can give us bread. (a3) Cute mutters something between his teeth, then approaches Shestan and talks to him in a whisper. Shestan tells him to listen to the dervish, while checking the surroundings.

6 Great Allah! Can’t you see the devil wants to do away with Albania? He wants the women’s veils ripped open! But a woman with her veil torn isn’t a woman anymore but a whore, and whole of Albania becomes a brothel. (CONTINUED)

66  s.63 p.67. AHMET(cont'd) But You, 0 Great Allah, You won’t allow this to happen, and us your humble servants, we are ready for sacrifice, and we will hang these infidels and miscreants by their feet! As the dervish goes on with his speech, Shestan and his companions look at the faces of those listening. Suddenly group of religious kids dressed in white robes come out f the mosque, running threateningly, and they join the listeners, sitting down cross legged. Shestan is getting suspicious and feels the situation is turning acid. (a2) AHMET (cont’d) We don’t want an Albania with three religions, but a free Albania, with the one and only true religion, that of Mohammed’s! What must be, must be, my sons. Allah gave me this life, and if Allah requests it, I will gladly give him back. The crowd pray and psalmody: CROWD . Thank you, thank you! 0 Dervish Ahmet ! Ahmet kneels on his rock and chants his prayers with his closed. The crowd follows. Suddenly, the dervish stops hi prayer, stands, and points at the fighters.
What are you looking for, brothers?
We’d like to buy food. We pay for it in cash.
What are you?
We’re just people. Trying to join the war.
The war is over, captain. The king ran away like a rat. Allah saved us all. Allah is great! Allahu akhbar! He gives us war and he gives us bread. (CONTINUED)

You are mistaken, 0 dervish. Men are those who make the war! Ahmet the dervish refuses to answer, climbs down the rock heads for the mosque, leaning on his walking stick. As Shestan’s fighters leave the small square, kids follow th and throw stones at them. They do not react. SHESTAN (cont’d) Let it be, they’re just kids. They don’t know what they’re doing.
That filthy moocher! with all the stink, still talking about God! The kids have stopped at the end of the square, and keep throwing stones at the fighters, mocking them until they disappear.
The Inn appears in the background. The detachment of the fighters can hardly walk any longer. They are crushed wit fatigue. Cute stops and spits on the ground angrily.
Where’s the war, captain? Seems to be running away from us all the time. Don’t think we’re getting anywhere, captain. We’re exhausted, walking night and day. Shestan answers him sharply.
You asking me where the war is? How should I know, Cute?! We set off for war together. If we can’t find it, it’s nobody’s fault. And stop screaming as if they were slaughtering you.

The hell with war! I want to go back to the village. We had to leave our homes, our wives and kids, for this damned war. But what do you know, anyway? You have neither wife nor kids. Shestan is silent. Cute keeps walking and the other fight follow him. Shestan is left behind. 68  65 66 s.65 p.69.

Sunset. Agnes the Nun is walking fast on the road. She tu her head towards the setting sun. It’s dusk already. She quickens her step, scared. On the other side of the road, sees herself, wearing Shestan’s coat. Agnes stops and loo at her. Agnes with the coat takes the hand of Agnes the N and they walk away.
I know where he is.
Where?
I can’t tell you. Follow me! Agnes the Nun doesn’t believe her. AGNES WITH THE COAT (cont’d) Look, his coat. He lost it on the way.
Tell me where he is!
He is on his way to his village. We must find him before he gets there. Once he’s there, he is getting married. His mom’s found a bride for him.

Getting married? Agnes with the coat takes her by the hand and pulls her, Agnes the Nun resists, pulls her hand away and runs to wh she was coming from. Agnes with the coat stands in the middle of the road. It starts raining. Agnes the Nun runs away terrified and disappears. Agnes opens her eyes, realizes she has been dreaming. She catches her breath, still terrified by the dream.
Candle in hand, the Skinny Nun is at Mother Superior’s do She cries.
Mother, open up, it’s me, Rosseta! Open the door, please! (CONTINUED)

69  67 s.66 p.70. Mother Superior opens the door, surprised by this late vi and asks Rosseta inside. SKINNY NUN (cont’d) Mother, may God forgive me! Sister Agnes has escaped! Mother Superior crosses herself. She fills a cup with wat and hands it to the crying Skinny Nun. She puts on her bl robe, and sits in front of her.

Listen, sister. Nobody must know she is gone. This is God’s will. It’s not your fault. The Skinny Nun can hardly stop sobbing. Mother Superior t to her softly. MOTHER SUPERIOR (cont’d) Rosseta, sister Agnes is not going to come back. She has chosen her own way. That’s life, my dear. A long and winding road, with no end in sight. The end, though, always comes to you. The Skinny Nun, troubled by these wise words, looks up at with affection.

location: HILL IN FRONT OF THE BLUE INN. NIGHTFALL 67

text: Kus Babaj follows Shestan’s fighters through his binocula (a4)
